title: Refactor Complex Queries for project_imports(from)
description:
project_imports metrics are identified as having complex queries and discrepancies with Automated Service Ping

Implementation https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data.rb#L891

Metrics to fix

```
usage_activity_by_stage_monthly => manage: => {:gitlab_project=>0, :gitlab=>0, :github=>0, :bitbucket=>0, :bitbucket_server=>0, :gitea=>0, :git=>0, :manifest=>0, :gitlab_migration=>0, :total=>0}
```
 
* usage_activity_by_stage { manage { project_imports { total } } [source code](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data.rb#L873)

```sql
"total": "SELECT (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'gitlab_project' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'gitlab' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'github' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'bitbucket' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'bitbucket_server' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'gitea' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'git' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'manifest' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"bulk_import_entities\".\"id\") FROM \"bulk_import_entities\" WHERE \"bulk_import_entities\".\"source_type\" = 1)"
``` 

* usage_activity_by_stage_monthly { manage { project_imports { "total" } } [source code](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data.rb#L873)

```sql
"total": "SELECT (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'gitlab_project' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'gitlab' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'github' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'bitbucket' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'bitbucket_server' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'gitea' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'git' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"projects\".\"id\") FROM \"projects\" WHERE \"projects\".\"import_type\" = 'manifest' AND \"projects\".\"import_type\" IS NOT NULL) + (SELECT COUNT(\"bulk_import_entities\".\"id\") FROM \"bulk_import_entities\" WHERE \"bulk_import_entities\".\"created_at\" BETWEEN '2021-12-27 06:42:59.923192' AND '2022-01-24 06:42:59.923266' AND \"bulk_import_entities\".\"source_type\" = 1)"
``` 
  

# Acceptance criteria

For each identified complex database metric, we want to look into:

1. Refactor to Make the logic simple, to only use `count` or `distinct_count`
1. Overwrite `to_sql` if required, with the correct query for DWH
1. The logic for the query generated for DWH should be the same, we should be able to get in the end the same values


Related to #349858

title: Geo Sites Tests - Explicit mock data for Primary and Secondary Nodes
description:
The following discussion from !79070 should be addressed:

- [ ] @a_akgun started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/79070#note_825192074): 

    > @zcuddy 
    > 
    > optional nitpick thought: I wonder if we should rather have `MOCK_PRIMARY_NODES` and `MOCK_SECONDARY_NODES` as a constant to eliminate the risk that a future MR modifies `MOCK_NODES` leaving no secondary ones or vice versa.

### What / Why

This is a greater issue than just the one noted by @a_akgun.  There are a lot of places in the `spec/frontend/geo_nodes` tests directory where we _assume_ that the nodes in `MOCK_NODES` will be exactly 1 Primary and 1 Secondary.  This makes the tests really brittle if we ever needed to change this mock data format.

### Proposal
1. Break out `MOCK_NODES` into `MOCK_PRIMARY_NODES` and `MOCK_SECONDARY_NODES` so that the tests can be more explicit and solid about what they are expecting.
2. Update usages across the testing directory

title: Metrics dictionary - automatically designate "Introduced by URL"
description:
## Summary

In metrics.gitlab.com we have a column available called "Introduced by URL", this is a manually added value which identifies where a metric was introduced. Unfortunately since this is a manual field we don't have comprehensive data. We should automate this.

## Proposal

We should automate the writing of this data point with either the issue or MR which introduce the metric.

title: Metrics dictionary - sorting "introduced by url" not working as expected
description:
## Summary

When attempting to sort the `introduced by url` in metrics.gitlab.com, the column doesn't properly sort by existing data. 

## Steps to reproduce

1. Add `introduced by url` to viewable columns
1. Select the sort carrot next to `introduced by url` column 
1. Notice that it appears to have sorted (the carrot icon changes) but the column data doesn't actually change

Example of various sorting action which showed more data in the `introduced by url` column:
![Kapture_2022-01-28_at_10.59.48](/uploads/5c12417fafc946ac8b93266a0655921e/Kapture_2022-01-28_at_10.59.48.gif)

## Success criteria

- Upgrade the library as we're using an _old_ version because of a [known bug](https://github.com/grid-js/gridjs-vue/issues/427)
- Implement [custom sorting](https://gridjs.io/docs/examples/custom-sort) to make sure it can handle these cases.

title: Frontend: Rename commit target branch to avoid confusion
description:
<!-- This issue template can be used as a great starting point for feature requests. The section "Release notes" can be used as a summary of the feature and is also required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated using the release post item generator:  https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#release-post-item-generator. The remaining sections are the backbone for every feature in GitLab.

The goal of this template is brevity for quick/smaller iterations. For a more thorough list of considerations for larger features or feature sets, you can leverage the detailed [feature proposal](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/.gitlab/issue_templates/Feature%20proposal%20-%20detailed.md). -->

### Release notes

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve

The branch you're committing to in the pipeline editor is called "target branch". Let's say you're committing to a branch `new-feature`. It would be considered the *source* branch, and `main` would actually be considered the target branch.

![image](/uploads/5fe3ceca825f9b2c4d12d51a2cf5f125/image.png)

#### Further details

<details><summary>Click to expand</summary>

- More context [in this thread.](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/351459#note_834704973)

The following discussion from !79032 should be addressed:

- [ ] @zcuddy started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/79032#note_824180753):  (+1 comment)

    > **nitpick (super-non-blocking):** We could utilize the same variable name `sourceBranch` rather than renaming it to `commitBranch` to take advantage of the shorthand.  This is more of a style preference, I just noticed since we were reassigning the value twice.
    > 
    > ```js
    > const sourceBranch = targetBranch;
    > const params = openMergeRequest
    >   ? {
    >       type: COMMIT_SUCCESS_WITH_REDIRECT,
    >       params: {
    >         sourceBranch,
    >         targetBranch: this.currentBranch,
    >       },
    >     }
    >   : { type: COMMIT_SUCCESS };
    > ```

The source branch of the MR is the target branch of the commit, and the target branch of the MR is the current branch the user is on. This is very confusing and should be changed in the UI and in the code

</details>


<!-- What is the user problem you are trying to solve with this issue? -->

### Proposal

Rename the "target branch" in the pipeline editor commit form to just "branch" to avoid confusion.

title: EE::Project#sourced_pipelines overrides homonym association in Core
description:
## Problem

While investigating an unrelated behavior I noticed that `EE::Project` defines a `has_many :sourced_pipelines` association that has a wrong type. Instead of pointing to `Ci::Sources::Pipeline` it uses `Ci::Sources::Project`.

The problem here is not just the naming but the fact that in Core we do have [`Project#sourced_pipelines`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/a5331e7742909d6e227854401579b6caf4eeefeb/app/models/project.rb#L366) and in EE we are overriding this to return a different type.

## Solution

Drop the override in EE if not needed or rename the association.

After checking that the association was only used in specs today, we can drop it.

title: ci_namespace_mirrors and ci_project_mirrors consistency check
description:
From: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/346786#note_821348824

> So far we validated this manually that this is coherent. I wonder if we can somehow have a semi-automatic/or-automatic way to do this validation to ensure the consistency between data. Some ideas:
> 
> * Run the above queries as part of rake task, but taking into account the decomposed database
> * Run the above queries by cron, by doing a sampling/randomisation of a small subset of the `ci_namespace_mirrors` and by statistical significance over longer period we effectively check each record
> 
> I think the most important is comparing the coherence between `traversal_ids`, less relevent if we have extra records present in `ci_namespace_mirrors` vs `namespaces`. This responsibility of validating deletion behavior is more related to loose foreign key implementation.
> 
> Likely we should document approaches and proposals as part of a follow-up.

title: Invite new user and sign in via SSO returns 404 error (Project and Group Invite)
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

When a **new** user is invited via email to a group or project, if they accept the invite and sign in via SSO, after login, they will be redirected to 404 page not found `https://gitlab.com/groups/groupname/-/activity`

Bug is reported by [Premium customer](https://gitlab.my.salesforce.com/0016100000ATRo6AAH) via [Internal Ticket](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/252528). ([All GitLab team members can view](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/support/internal-support/#viewing-support-tickets))

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create new private group `example-group`
1. Invite a user via email
1. Click `Join Now` from the email
1. Click Create Account using `Google` (or Sign in with any other SSO)
   1. Accept Terms if needed
1. Gets a 404 page `https://gitlab.com/groups/groupname/-/activity`

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/groups/te3054/-/group_members?tab=invited

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

User was presented with a 404 page after signing in via SSO (User does not have an account and logs in for the first time) The same applies to project invite. 

Upon checking the group/project permission, we noticed the email is still at `Invited` tab and the relevant permission was not applied to the new user correctly, hence the 404 page.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Correctly apply the permission to the user after account creation after SSO login, user should be able to view the group's activity page.

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com (14.8.0-pre 3bf32596aaf), we also tested on `14.1.2` and `14.4.2`

### Investigation Notes

- We're unsure if this is a ~regression from this possible change: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/56695
- It seems like after the user creation, the token expires, and the group member permission is not applied to the new user.
- If we invite the user again, it will work as their user is already created.

title: EventStore - Define EE-only subscribers
description:
## Problem

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/79291#note_824349792 we realized that the way we can define EE-only subscribers is not ideal since the subscriptions are only declared in Core (`lib/gitlab/event_store.rb`).

To enable a EE subscriber for now we need to create a no-op subscriber in Core and extend it in EE with actual work. This is not ideal because we would dispatch events to subscribers and the jobs are enqueued even though they do nothing.

## Solution

We could define `ee/lib/ee/gitlab/event_store.rb` where we define EE-only subscribers and then extend the Core EventStore using `prepend_mod_with`.

title: Spike: Evaluate the approach of delivering Slack for Self-Managed First
description:
## Investigation

As discussed in our Integrations Weekly meeting, Slack suggested some benefits to deploying to Self-Managed customers first. We can more quickly iterate, release new features to customers, and then batch larger units of value into packages to push through the Slack Approval process for .com. On our end, we could also engage internal and Beta customers who are using Self-Managed GitLab and Slack to get rapid feedback and validation as we roll out updates.

For this Spike, we'd like to evaluate the approach and identify any blockers/challenges, and if possible, set up a process or framework for development moving forward. If the team prefers .com first based on this investigation, we'll just need to come back around to figure out how to roll updates from .com to Self-Managed at a later date.

## Questions 

- What's the recommended approach? 
- What will allow us to iterate and provide value to customers most quickly?
- What is the process/documentation for rolling out updates or getting started on a new Slack feature/update?
- What is the process for bundling up features delivered through App Manifests to Self-managed customers into GitLab.com updates?

## Resources

- Review GitLab-specific [Slack App Update Guidance](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1wXePct8JiG1qrLAgjWX3sy8Xoi8gMHlImDBFxJAcZfs/edit?usp=sharing) from Adam @ Slack regarding [App Manifests](https://api.slack.com/reference/manifests)
- General [Migration guide for classic Slack apps](https://api.slack.com/authentication/migration)

title: Fix undefined this in `toMatchInterpolatedText` utility
description:
### Summary When an assertion that uses `toMatchInterpolatedText` custom matcher fails, the resulting error message does not indicate why the test has failed. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Find an assertion that uses `toMatchInterpolatedText` 1. Change the expected value 1. Run the test ### Example Project ### What is the current *bug* behavior? `toMatchInterpolatedText` fails with `TypeError: Cannot read property 'utils' of undefined` error ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? The error message should indicate why the test has failed and should look like: ``` Expected to be: Received: ``` ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots Example failure: ``` TypeError: Cannot read property 'utils' of undefined 23 | ` 24 | \n\n > 25 | Expected: ${this.utils.printExpected(clearReceived)} | ^ 26 | To equal: ${this.utils.printReceived(clearMatch)} 27 | `; 28 | at message (spec/frontend/__helpers__/matchers/to_match_interpolated_text.js:25:24) at getMessage (node_modules/expect/build/index.js:173:15) at processResult (node_modules/expect/build/index.js:289:25) at Object.toMatchInterpolatedText (node_modules/expect/build/index.js:358:16) ``` ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes Custom matchers are object methods and `toMatchInterpolatedText` matcher is currently defined as an arrow function. Object methods should be traditional functions to be able to access appropriate `this`. A possible fix is to change the arrow function to a traditional function. The other two matchers [to_have_sprite_icon.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/spec/frontend/__helpers__/matchers/to_have_sprite_icon.js) and [to_have_tracking_attributes.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/spec/frontend/__helpers__/matchers/to_have_tracking_attributes.js) should be fine as they don't access `this`. [Specification for arrow function as methods](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/Arrow_functions#description) [Custom matcher example provided by Jest](https://jestjs.io/docs/expect#thisutils)

title: Fix tabbing through disabled buttons on cluster_list
description:
## Context

The following discussion from !77407 should be addressed:

- [ ] @pslaughter started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/77407#note_822718574):  (+3 comments)

    > > I changed the tabindex for the tooltips to -1 instead, so that they are no longer focusable with tab, and that seems to make everything work correctly. Only 1 tab to move to the next element, and the button can still be activated with enter when tab-focused.
    > 
    > There's a downside to `tabindex="-1"` on the wrapping element when the underlying button is disabled. With `tabindex="0"` the disabled button will receive focus and the tooltip will show up. With `tabindex="-1"` and a disabled button, then the tab will skip over the disabled button.
    > 
    > ![Screencast_2022-01-27_15_03_39](/uploads/3628026d14060e3391e0c6abc964afe3/Screencast_2022-01-27_15_03_39.webm)
    > 
    > I think this is non-blocking because most users will be able to still hover over the disabled button to get the tooltip, but it would be great to create a small follow-up (maybe even with a ~"good for new contributors") for this :thumbsup:

## Implementation guide

Here's the places we'll want to update.

- [`clusters_view_all.vue#L183`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d3e7d20e90b8999a658b725955f7caccbbb471f5/app/assets/javascripts/clusters_list/components/clusters_view_all.vue#L183)
- [`clusters_view_all.vue#L232`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d3e7d20e90b8999a658b725955f7caccbbb471f5/app/assets/javascripts/clusters_list/components/clusters_view_all.vue#L232)
- [`delete_agent_button.vue#L160`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d3e7d20e90b8999a658b725955f7caccbbb471f5/app/assets/javascripts/clusters_list/components/delete_agent_button.vue#L160)

See the [bootstrap-vue docs](https://bootstrap-vue.org/docs/components/tooltip#disabled-elements) and above discussion for possible fixes.

See the instructions in [this MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/77407) for how to set up clusters in the local gdk.

title: Spike: Define the Security Model for the Slack Application Update
description:
## Investigation

This focus of this issue is to be a time-boxed investigation of our current security model and to define/propose a new model that will support our future updates.

## Questions

* How should an integration be administered?
* Can an integration be enabled at the Group level (via a Group owner)? Can we then control what Projects are enabled/available for users to configure (e.g. lock or disable some projects from being able to use the integration)?
* How can an individual access/manage/configure their integration?
* How will public links be unfurled vs private links based on the users permissions?
* Must we federate Slack and GitLab to leverage permissions? 
* What engineering tasks need to be defined to implement the new security model? (such as for Federation, database tables, APIs, or other components)
* Will the Slack App be cognizant of projects vs groups?

## Todos
- [ ] Create new issues off of this issue
- [ ] Close this issue and use for reference
